title: 110_hr285
content: The Act may be cited as the "Steel Industry National Historic Site Act" and includes findings and purposes. The Steel Industry National Historic Site Act aims to preserve significant historical structures in Pennsylvania related to the steel industry, such as the United States Steel Homestead Works and the Carrie Furnace complex, which are at risk of being lost without federal assistance. The Steel Industry National Historic Site Act aims to preserve significant historical structures in Pennsylvania related to the steel industry for the benefit of present and future generations. The Steel Industry National Historic Site Act aims to preserve significant historical structures in Pennsylvania related to the steel industry. The Steel Industry National Historic Site is established in Pennsylvania, including properties related to the former United States Steel Homestead Works. This includes the historic Battle of Homestead site in Munhall, Pennsylvania. The Steel Industry National Historic Site in Pennsylvania includes the historic Carrie Furnace complex in Swissvale and Rankin, with blast furnaces, ore yard, cast house, and other structures. It also encompasses the Hot Metal Bridge location. The Hot Metal Bridge, part of the Steel Industry National Historic Site in Pennsylvania, spans the Monongahela River connecting mill sites in Rankin and Munhall. The Secretary of the Interior may acquire property for the historic site by donation, including land adjacent to the bridge. The Secretary of the Interior may acquire property for the Steel Industry National Historic Site in Pennsylvania for visitor facilities and interpretation of the historic site. Private property owners are not required to allow public access, and existing laws regarding public access to private property are not affected. The site will be administered in accordance with laws applicable to the National Park System. The Secretary of the Interior can enter into cooperative agreements with individuals or organizations to further the purposes of the Steel Industry National Historic Site until the property is acquired. Any payments made under these agreements are subject to conditions to prevent misuse of the site. The Secretary of the Interior may provide technical assistance for the preservation of historic structures and maintenance of the natural landscape at the historic site. Within three years of funding availability, a general management plan incorporating feedback must be prepared for the site. The Secretary must consult with relevant officials and property owners for the general management plan of the historic site, and submit it to Congress upon completion. Authorization of up to $30,000,000 is approved for the development of the historic site, to be reported to the Committees on Natural Resources and Energy in Congress.
